sections.title: What Is Wastewater?
sections.content: Wastewater is water that has been used in homes, businesses, or industries and contains contaminants such as human waste, food particles, soaps, oils, and chemicals.
bullets: Domestic (toilets, showers, sinks)
Industrial processes
Stormwater runoff

sections.title: Why Treat Wastewater?
bullets: Protect public health by removing pathogens
Prevent pollution in rivers, lakes, and oceans
Comply with environmental regulations
Recover resources (e.g., water reuse, biosolids, energy)

sections.title: What even is Wastewater Treatment?
sections.content: Wastewater treatment is speeding up the natural purification of water. Bacteria and other organisms naturally consume food sources and waste in water. Due to the sheer amount of waste we produce, we built treatment plants to speed up that natural process instead of overloading our waterways. After speeding up the natural process, most wastewater plants will disinfect the water to cleanse it of any harmful microorganisms before discharging the water.

subsections.title: Preliminary Treatment
subsections.content: Removes large debris that can damage equipment or clog systems. This stage is largely focused on protecting the plant.
bullets: Bar Screens – remove large objects like rags or sticks that can cause damage to pumps when sucked in.
Grit Chambers – settle out sand, gravel, and other heavy particles. These inorganic particles can damage equipment and settle in tanks, taking up valuable space.

subsections.title: Primary Treatment
subsections.content: Settles out solids by gravity in large tanks. The goal here is to have floatable solids skimmed off the top of the water and settleable solids scraped out the bottom of the tank, leaving
bullets: Primary Clarifiers – remove ~50–60% of suspended solids and some BOD

subsections.title: Secondary Treatment
subsections.content: Uses biological processes to remove organic matter.
bullets: Activated Sludge Process – microorganisms break down organic material in aeration tanks
Trickling Filters – fixed-bed systems that support microbial growth
Secondary Clarifiers – separate treated water from biological solids

subsections.title: Tertiary (Advanced) Treatment
subsections.content: Removes remaining nutrients, solids, or pathogens.
bullets: Filtration – sand or membrane filters
Nutrient Removal – nitrification/denitrification, phosphorus precipitation
Disinfection – chlorine, UV, or ozone to kill pathogens before discharge

sections.title: Solids Handling
sections.content: Solids from treatment are processed further:
bullets: Thickening – concentrates sludge
Digestion – stabilizes organic material (aerobic or anaerobic)
Dewatering – removes water (e.g., belt presses)
Disposal or reuse – landfill, composting, or land application

sections.title: Key Parameters Operators Must Monitor
bullets: BOD – how much oxygen microbes need to break down organics
TSS (Total Suspended Solids) – solid particles in water
pH – acidity/alkalinity
DO (Dissolved Oxygen) – vital for biological treatment
Flow rate – affects detention time and treatment performance
Chlorine residual – for disinfection effectiveness

sections.title: Operator Responsibilities
bullets: Monitor and adjust equipment
Perform laboratory tests and record results
Maintain safe and clean facilities
Understand safety procedures and emergency protocols
Stay compliant with regulatory permits

sections.title: Study Tips for Grade 1 Operators
bullets: Know definitions and functions of equipment
Understand basic math and lab calculations (e.g., flow, loading rates)
Memorize treatment stages and what each removes
Review safety and chemical handling procedures
Take practice tests and review your state’s certification guide
